text: agrarian life by jazz, Lauren, and Sloane. The day in the life of an agrarian worker. Hi, my name is William. I'm married to a lovely lady named Mary, the mother of my two children, James, 6, and Anne 10. Today is April 15th, 1817, and I start my day at 6 a.m. to begin my wonderful agrarian life. This life is any community whose economy is based on producing and maintaining crops as well as farmland. The agrarian life allows for our families to live on farms producing products for ourselves and the economy, with less labor than factory workers and new machines being used, allowing for more time on our hands. I begin the day by dressing myself with the most sustainable products made from our cotton gin. The machine that we use daily helps assist mass production of cotton. The cotton gin could generate up to 50 pounds of clean cotton daily and make cotton production profitable for us increasing our wages. Then I go downstairs to eat the supplers of foods and products that my neighbors and I have produced. Every day we become less fearful if there will be food on our plates for each meal. I start my baking breakfast and then head out to work on the farm. My day consists of hard, rewarding work that benefits my family in many ways. My children are able to play on the farm while I work, and my wife is able to homeschool our children, assuring their education is in good hands. With the amount of land we have on our farm, they are able to learn by exploring the world and nature around us. We keep ourselves busy each day by doing many different tasks, but my mind continues to wander and think about the families who aren't as fortunate to live in a growing life like us. With the urban lifestyle becoming more popular and growing rapidly, many people have begun to move away. Recently, the families of my childhood friends moved to the city to pursue an urban life for the reason of opportunities. However, most of them ended up working in a factory for countless hours on days ending in unhealthy conditions, as well as their beloved children working in the coal mines. To keep my family safe, this is why we chose to continue to live life on the farm. During this time, farms became the healthier and safer options. Farms allowed agrarians with fresh air, not having to deal with smoke or snot. The spread of many diseases was extremely low, as agrarians had moral land to distance themselves from others to limit the spread of smallpox, typhus, and tuberculosis. Whereas my childhood friends lived in crowded places with no privacy, as well as dangerous accidents occurring frequently. After I got my food, I went down to the farm. I used my new plow to break up the soil and help control weeds. Then I used my threshing machine to take the dead seeds out of the soil. To evenly distribute the fresh seeds, I used my seed drill in even straight rows. Due to the increasing amount of technological advancements, we gained more freedom. The development and advancement of tools and machines decreased the demand for rural labor. We used different types of ways to grow crops on the farm, including crop rotation. Crop rotation grew more food using the same amount of land, providing us with a surplus that has a variety of unlimited foods, increasing the farmer's salaries. By the end of the day, I'm no longer in pain from the consistent and aggressive workout on the farm. I'm now able to just manage my machines, causing my day on the farm to be shortened. Since I'm no longer on the farm from dusk to dawn, I'm able to spend more time with my family and bond with them. Each night we have fresh home-cooked meals made by my wonderful wife, who is sometimes assisted by my lovely children. We then sit down and talk about our day. We have fun playing games and just socializing with each other. About once a week, we will have neighbors over whose children's age are just the same as mine. I enjoyed this time very much. As years ago, I didn't have this time and would still be out in the fields working. To finish off my day, I get ready for bed and to do it all over again the next few days. Thank you so much for watching our presentation. I would highly suggest putting a vote down for our group, and for a little reminder that aggrurant life is what started it all.

The day in the life of an agrarian worker.
Hi, my name is William. I'm married to a lovely lady named Mary, the mother of my two children, James, 6, and Anne 10.
Today is April 15th, 1817, and I start my day at 6 a.m. to begin my wonderful agrarian life.
This life is any community whose economy is based on producing and maintaining crops as well as farmland.
The agrarian life allows for our families to live on farms producing products for ourselves and the economy,
with less labor than factory workers and new machines being used, allowing for more time on our hands.
I begin the day by dressing myself with the most sustainable products made from our cotton gin.

The cotton gin could generate up to 50 pounds of clean cotton daily and make cotton production profitable for us increasing our wages.

Every day we become less fearful if there will be food on our plates for each meal.
I start my baking breakfast and then head out to work on the farm.
My day consists of hard, rewarding work that benefits my family in many ways.

assuring their education is in good hands.
With the amount of land we have on our farm, they are able to learn by exploring the world and nature around us.
We keep ourselves busy each day by doing many different tasks,
but my mind continues to wander and think about the families who aren't as fortunate to live in a growing life like us.
With the urban lifestyle becoming more popular and growing rapidly, many people have begun to move away.
Recently, the families of my childhood friends moved to the city to pursue an urban life for the reason of opportunities.

as well as their beloved children working in the coal mines.
To keep my family safe, this is why we chose to continue to live life on the farm.
During this time, farms became the healthier and safer options.
Farms allowed agrarians with fresh air, not having to deal with smoke or snot.

to limit the spread of smallpox, typhus, and tuberculosis.
Whereas my childhood friends lived in crowded places with no privacy, as well as dangerous accidents occurring frequently.
After I got my food, I went down to the farm.
I used my new plow to break up the soil and help control weeds.

We then sit down and talk about our day. We have fun playing games and just socializing with each other.
About once a week, we will have neighbors over whose children's age are just the same as mine.
I enjoyed this time very much. As years ago, I didn't have this time and would still be out in the fields working.
To finish off my day, I get ready for bed and to do it all over again the next few days.
Thank you so much for watching our presentation. I would highly suggest putting a vote down for our group, and for a little reminder that aggrurant life is what started it all.
